243416: Knight of the Reliquary.author: lungsoftheocean
243416: Knight of the Reliquary.text_parsed:
Before I say anything about the art (ehem, old version, *cough*) let me say that this is one of my favorite cards in MTG. This plus Lotus Cobra is nearly impossible to stop. Lets think about the infinite application for KotR-

-Mana-fixing made easy.
-Early game 4/4 that gets bigger easily.
-Recycle used mana mid-turn.
-Turn 3 Baneslayer Angel with Lotus Cobra.
-Thins out your deck quickly.
etc
etc
etc

Great flavor text, great title, great artwork, endless usability, all for 3 measly mana. Win.

243416: Knight of the Reliquary.author: Lateralis0ne
243416: Knight of the Reliquary.text_parsed:
This is one of two cards I know of where Michael Komarck did the initial artwork, and Wayne Reynolds followed up with a promo version; the other card being Rafiq of the Many.

Dunno why that sounded important, but hey, the more you know!

Both images are excellent; I love Wayne Reynolds for his great stylization of characters, and Michael Komarck has some great detail in his pieces (my personal favorite being Horizon Canopy).

And the card's mechanics are incredible, at the least. Not even mana-fixing; fetching utility lands at instant speed, getting them to the battlefield in the same ability, and being able to do anything from exiling an opponent's graveyard to granting your creatures protection to stopping an attacking creature...it gets awesome, once you get thinking.

5/5 for flavor, mechanics, BOTH versions of art, and conceptualization.

243416: Knight of the Reliquary.author: raptorman333
243416: Knight of the Reliquary.text_parsed:
play with crucible of worlds for a fallback plan or to just get a lot of lands out--become {T} search your library for a land and put it into play--you won't have to worry about the dead land draw-back. with tideforce elemental, you basically can pull all the lands out of your deck and then, with the crucible, have no problem getting playing one each turn, that way you're always drawing something useful. just need a card like stormtide leviathan to keep the combo running.

(citation to Mishras-Prodigy for tideforce elemental)

243416: Knight of the Reliquary.author: ParallaxtheRevan
243416: Knight of the Reliquary.text_parsed:
I appreciate this card on power, I guess, but I dislike it just barely slightly on Flavor, as it doesn't seem to be quite right at all for 'Knight Tribal'- from a Vorthos perspective anyway. This one is clearly a 'Lone Ranger' type, and my reaction to it is they've been a lot of places, seen a lot of things, and it's that experience they have that gives them their strength.

In some ways, it draws power from lands almost in the same way a Wizard or a Planeswalker does! While that is very neat flavor indeed, for a singleton Mythic creature card in some of my decks, for Knight Tribal I would prefer to put in Juniper Order Ranger as my Green-White creature. I don't know that's just how I think...

243416: Knight of the Reliquary.author: Doaj
243416: Knight of the Reliquary.text_parsed: It is reprinted at Mythic status because it's the focal point of the Knights half of the deck. Just like in Divine vs Demonic, where Lord of the Pit was printed at Mythic, not because it needed to be at that rarity, or because it was that absurd, but because it was the focal point of that deck, KotR is key. Yes, Mythics were introduced in that set. But KotR is playable in it's power, and Wizards has said they don't want to print Mythics that dominate formats. In that vein, Hero of Bladehold will not make waves in Legacy, or probably even Modern, and even only saw fringe play in Standard. But she's powerful. She plays well with others. And newer players, pulling her as a Mythic in a pack, will see her being a lot more powerful than they see KotR. And that's exactly what the Mythic rarity is for. To make new players think thu just pulled something jaw-droopingly powerful. A new player will think, "This is good." Looking at KotR. Looking at Lorthos, they'll think, "This is incredible." The difference is important.

243421: Knight of Cliffhaven.author: DarthParallax
243421: Knight of Cliffhaven.text_parsed:
level up should have either let you get better abilities than a Serra Angel, or as good as, but for less total mana. If first level was 3/3, this would have been more playable. The problem is, level up as a mechanic is like the aura card type: its got some innate disadvantages built into it, since your opponent can just wait for you to pay the level mana then blow you out.

Hero of Destiny was good at every level. Most of the level guys sucked until they were all the way leveled. I think the only one that saw any constructed play was a Mythic Rare- Kargan Dragonlord. If there were others, I didn't notice them.

243422: Knight of Meadowgrain.author: DarthParallax
243422: Knight of Meadowgrain.text_parsed:
ok she's pretty, I will definitely give you that. but...I dunno.

I'm not too fond of using an army of Kithkin. I much prefer saving just one or two of my sixty for them, for really special guys like the Kinsbaile Cavalier.

The Lord of the Rings battles were great because the silly hobbits had their moments, but most of the focus was still on epic serious guys. Comic relief or lightheartedness in battle should be the exception, not the norm, for maximum effect. That said, I wouldn't dream of actually playing 0 of her either. At least 1, cuz the card really is very good.

I'm a very picky deck-builder. I overthink it and use subjective standards, as a defense mechanism against going to the 'dark side' of Magic and just playing Caw-Blade, Jund, Faeries, Affinity, or whatever the CurbStompU deck of the time is.

243425: Silver Knight.author: DarthParallax
243425: Silver Knight.text_parsed:
I think it's possible that Silver Knight would have been better to just keep its old artwork in the new frame. The artwork is the only point you can possibly have a quibble about. The card is fantastic and the Duel Deck's flavor text quote against Dragons is strictly better.

So, about the art: White Knight, Black Knight, and Blood Knight all nearly over-do it on matching the tones of the cards' art to the name of the card. This Silver Knight has Silver...but also other colors, and it's those other colors that are distracting me a bit and making it harder to tell the difference between him and White Knight than I would have liked.

To be perfectly honest, I want them to make a Blue Knight and a Green Knight, and I want them to do it with overdosed solid color schemes, so that I can make a deck that's exactly like the Mighty Morphin' Power Rangers: costumes look almost stupid, but you can't get away with telling them so cuz they'll kick your ass.

Gold Knight would be a 3/3 first strike for and protection from everything. cuz the Sixth Ranger is always broken in half. xD

243425: Silver Knight.author: EDHDeckbuilder
243425: Silver Knight.text_parsed:
There are 112 cards carrying the "Dragon" subtype. Of those, there are 8 with a basic toughness of less than 2. Of those, 5 have flying by default. Of the 3 remaining, Dragon Egg spawns a 2/2 flying dragon upon dying, Hellkite Hatchling turns into a 3/3 trampler if you sac something for it, and Tek can get +2/+2, flying, trample, and first strike depending on what lands you've got in play. So, of the 112 Dragon subtype card, the Silver Knight may be able to kill off three of them, and more likely just one, which will then spawn a 2/2 flying creature that he can't reach. 30 of them do are not red, and all of them are capable of eating him. So for all his tough-guy dragon-slayer flavour text, he's really not all that much for hunting dragons.

That said, WW is solid for a 2/2 first-striker in my book, with colour protection as a bonus. It's also great art, and I like the flavour text, despite how ill-fitting it may be.

243426: White Knight.author: DarthParallax
243426: White Knight.text_parsed:
dummies. asking them to make Duel Decks: Knights vs. Dragons without including one of either Black Knight or White Knight is like asking them to make
Duel Decks: Jace vs. Chandra without Counterspell and Incinerate (complete with Jaya Ballard quote, DAMN YOU M12!!!), or
Duel Decks: Angels vs. Demons without Akroma, Angel of Wrath and Lord of the Pit. or
Duel Decks: Phyrexia vs. the Coalition without Coaltion Relic, or
Duel Decks: Tezzeret vs. Elspeth without Crusade and Thirst for Knowledge.

Or Premium Deck Series: Fire & Lightning without 4x Lightning Bolt

I would not have been surprised to see White Knight as a four-of. and EVEN though they decided on mono-red for the Dragon deck, when Red-Black could have been more interesting and made this card better, White Knight is STILL one of the best cards in the Knight deck. Silver Knight utterly rapes if you draw it. White Knight feels like a 'fixed' Silver Knight in Knights vs. Dragons. First Strike on a fast-to-cast creature is still just great.

I do hope this is the last Mono-Red Duel Deck we see for a while. They kinda did that...alot.

243431: Knight Exemplar.author: Morgaledh
243431: Knight Exemplar.text_parsed:
To the Gate to Phyrexia rides the Knight Exemplar, her War Hawk perched on her wrist, her Attended Knight bearing a proud Capashen Standard, fluttering in the breeze as she surveys the Tainted Field before her. The Ring of Thune she wears glints in the Serene Sunset as she hefts her Loxodon Warhammer and shoulders her Angelic Armaments, gifts from Avacyn herself.

"Rally!" she cries to her Elite Vanguard. "Rally the Troops, and alert General Jarkeld that this Foul Presence will soon be Purged from the Living Lands!"

"Death or Glory!"

243431: Knight Exemplar.author: Vastator
243431: Knight Exemplar.text_parsed:
This card has a few attributes that make it great:

1) well priced, at a cost of 3 it is not only playable but also one hell of a threat that has top notch tribal support

2) it's effects and the way it influences the dynamics of a game are one of the best hands down

3) knights are annoying to play against; this only makes them a whole lot worse

4) +1/+1 and invincible? who doesn't want that?

5) you can only have 4 in one deck but if somehow we could have more we would.

summary: it's well priced, has excellent effects and tribal support, buffs up other knights and renders them nigh indestructible.



I run 4 of these in my deck, that's how much I like it ...

5/5

243432: Wilt-Leaf Cavaliers.author: SirZapdos
243432: Wilt-Leaf Cavaliers.text_parsed:
Solid card. P/T at or above curve and vigilance to boot. It survives Cone of Flame, Cinder Wall, Mudbutton Torchrunner (unless blocking or blocked by it), Thunder Dragon's ETB ability, and Ghostfire.

It won't survive Bogardan Hellkite, Fiery Fall, Seismic Strike, Spitting Earth or Jaws of Stone, but having your opponent waste that hihg-powered burn on this guy saves room for some of the knights' heavy hitters like Knight of the Reliquary or Kinsbale Cavalier.
243432: Wilt-Leaf Cavaliers.text_posted:
Solid card. P/T at or above curve and vigilance to boot. It survives [autocard]Cone of Flame[/autocard], [autocard]Cinder Wall[/autocard], [autocard]Mudbutton Torchrunner[/autocard] (unless blocking or blocked by it), [autocard]Thunder Dragon[/autocard]'s ETB ability, and [autocard]Ghostfire[/autocard].

243434: Kinsbaile Cavalier.author: Hayw00d0909
243434: Kinsbaile Cavalier.text_parsed:
When I bought the Knights vs. Dragons set, I wasn't planning on ever using any of the Knight cards, I was mainly after the new Bogardan Hellkite and some of the other dragons. After I saw that they included this and it's buddy, Knight Exemplar, I turned around and built a Knight deck.

-A very easily casted card with an efficient but fair mana cost.
-Power, Toughness and ability is just right.
-Art is humerous and the overall flavor is great.

Overall, this is an excellent addition to the Knight set, and one of my favorite cards from Knights vs. Dragons.

243435: Alaborn Cavalier.author: OmegaSerris
243435: Alaborn Cavalier.text_parsed:
@divine_exodus
"Hey, you want to break into you dad's porn collection or gun cabinet?"

I don't understand modern censorship. Why allow the things that pose a physical threat (acts of extreme violence) yet flip the *** (thanks proving my point, Gatherer) out over a swear word or a bit of nudity on TV? Not saying TV creates real life violence or that censorship is a good thing, just trying to understand the whole hypocrisy.

@sir_dwar
It really depends on the Plane. Like I could see some guns (like hunting rifles) on Innistrad as it seems like they would fit as it appears to be mimicking late 19th century Europe and especially in the Horror theme. Yet they only seem to use Bows and Crossbows. I could also see some form of guns being made on Ravnica, only magic based (And probably Izzet). I really think it is an (unofficial) policy of Wizards, not just an inconvenience of flavor. Whether that is good or bad is up for debate. And really, it doesn't effect the actually game much. It's mainly an artistic decision. We have Snipers, Cannons, hell I'm not even sure what this is...

243438: Juniper Order Ranger.author: kiseki
243438: Juniper Order Ranger.text_parsed:
Persist! (Kitchen Finks, Twilight Shepherd, Murderous Redcap)
Tokens! (Raise the Alarm, Spectral Procession, Battle Screech, Conqueror's Pledge, Nomads' Assembly, Verdant Embrace, Mycoloth, Fresh Meat)

This card is fun. It starts out innocuously just out of bolt range. Then after playing Conqueror's Pledge it is suddenly a 8/10. And unlike many creatures that get crazy big, this one had an effect on your other creatures. Instant speed token generators like raise the alarm become mini permanent giant growths!

243440: Harm's Way.author: 00zau

@yyukichigai
I agree 100%. Getting more effects like this would be really cool. Treat this as a white Lightning bolt, then expand to white equivalents to other red damage spells. Arc Trail? Redirect 2 damage from 1-2 creatures you control to 1-2 creatures. For disintegrate-style exile-if-creature-dies effects, have the white equivalents exile if lethal damage is assigned (bypassing indestructible, if it takes enough damage that it would die, it is exiled), compensate by having costs like X1W or XXW for X power versions and generally higher costs, both for the redirect (at about 2 redirect to 3 damage), and for the potential exile effect (maybe a +1 cmc for most).

One thing that could be neat would be redirect Tims, probably RW and 4 cmc, with tap, redirect one damage ability.

I think harms way is a really cool card, and would like to see a lot more effects like it.

243444: Reprisal.author: DarthParallax
243444: Reprisal.text_parsed:
'Why does Smite the Monstrous exist' ?

Because of the color pie. While this is sort of a neat card....it makes my stomach curl because if this exists, and Path to Exile exists, and Oblivion Ring, and Swords to Plowshares....

the White is better at removal than Red. And that feels very wrong to me.

In fact, with Wrath of God-types....White is better at destruction than Black or Red. That feels VERY wrong to me.

While the Game might honestly need Oblivion-Ring, it does need the others as much. Wrath of God was supposed to define White as only good at sweep, but this yet one more targeted removal spell that's above the curve IN GENERAL, and it's White so it's Off the Color Pie. Good for powering up your deck, but bad for Designing a good game.

I don't want to see another White targetted kill spell this good ever again. Each color is good at some things and bad at others for a reason. White doesn't need this to already be good, and reprinting it would be a huge mistake, since Doom Blade and its kind are the #1 biggest reason anyone even bothers with Black in general anymore.

Black has had some recent good rares, but they needed to almost overprint good Black Rares before they actually made Black competitive beyond supporting White, Red, or Blue.

243445: Test of Faith.author: Ragamander
243445: Test of Faith.text_parsed:
This is a great combat-trick, effectively giving a creature an extra 6 toughness (in one combat) for only . Since it is likely to survive because of that, the 3 additional power and toughness will come back to haunt your opponent. It is also a nightmare for burn, since it negates one spell, then likely forces two more spells to kill the original creature.

In my opinion, it is far better than its original version, Temper.

Also, this is probably the best way to respond when someone tries to Lightning Bolt your attacking Mirran Crusader.

The fact that it increases offensive power and adds the counters immediately is a big draw in my book. A particularly amusing thing to do is throw this on a non-First Strike creature blocking/blocked by a First Striker. Instead of being killed from First Strike damage, your critter winds up getting bigger just in time to lay a beatdown on the other guy.

243452: Grasslands.author: MrFluffyThing
243452: Grasslands.text_parsed:
The benefit to Evolving Wilds and Terramorphic Expanse is that you can drop it on your first turn, then immediately tap it and search for any basic land card, which comes into play tapped, and untaps on your following turn.

The benefit to this is that you can drop it, wait a turn, then search for any forest or plains (Including Dual Lands and Shocklands) and put them into play.

Personally, I'd just play Amulet of Vigor and get it over with. No point in wasting time!
243452: Grasslands.text_posted:
The benefit to [autocard]Evolving Wilds[/autocard] and [autocard]Terramorphic Expanse[/autocard] is that you can drop it on your first turn, then immediately tap it and search for any basic land card, which comes into play tapped, and untaps on your following turn.

The benefit to this is that you can drop it, wait a turn, then search for any forest or plains (Including Dual Lands and Shocklands) and put them into play. 

Personally, I'd just play [autocard]Amulet of Vigor[/autocard] and get it over with. No point in wasting time!

243452: Grasslands.author: CaptainBlue
243452: Grasslands.text_parsed:
In a deck, I'd prefer this over Evolving Wilds or Terramorphic Expanse because it allows you to draw before you sacrifice to bring in that untapped Forest or Plains. The new card you just drew could have an impact on which land type you decide to put onto the battlefield.

Let's say you play Grasslands with a Forest in hand; you would naturally assume that searching for a Plains is best. Then your next turn begins, and you draw that Plains. Now, because you already have your Plains, you may want to search for a Forest instead, allowing you to cast something like Garruk's Companion. With Wilds or Expanse you have less futuresight.

so,
pro - more informed decision
con - efficiency limited to
4/5
243452: Grasslands.text_posted:
In a [G][W] deck, I'd prefer this over [autocard]Evolving Wilds[/autocard] or [autocard]Terramorphic Expanse[/autocard] because it allows you to draw before you sacrifice to bring in that untapped [autocard]Forest [/autocard] or [autocard]Plains[/autocard]. The new card you just drew could have an impact on which land type you decide to put onto the battlefield. 

Let's say you play Grasslands with a Forest in hand; you would naturally assume that searching for a Plains is best. Then your next turn begins, and you draw that Plains. Now, because you already have your Plains, you may want to search for a Forest instead, allowing you to cast something like [autocard]Garruk's Companion[/autocard]. With Wilds or Expanse you have less futuresight.

so,
pro - more informed decision 
con - efficiency limited to [G][W]
[b]4/5[/b]

243452: Grasslands.text_parsed:
This cycle is awesome for budget EDH players.

Spent all your money on shocks/duals, or just using the ones you happen to already own? Now you don't need to shell out *** $40 a pop for the relevant fetches. Sure, these come into play tapped, but EDH is a slow format anyways.

Having to wait one more turn to fetch my shocks/duals is definitely worth the amount of cash I save by playing these.

243452: Grasslands.author: Bbone37
243452: Grasslands.text_parsed:
There is no way evolving wilds or terramorphic expanse are better than these fetch lands, imho. Yes this ETBs tapped, but they fetch non-basics, which ETB untapped.

You would obviously not use this peticular fetch land if you didn't need green or white at all, but there was a full cycle of these cards in Mirage.

MrFluffyThing, as for your example, you can play this turn 1 as well, and then during your upkeep fetch the land. It would be just the same as a turn 1 wilds or expanse, except this lets you get much more vaulable dual lands.

CaptainBlue, the efficiency of this card is not limited to only GW decks. Since these can fetch dual lands (shock or original), you can run this in a deck the uses either g or w. Also, I repect your opinion about being able to draw a card first before choosing which land type you get, but personally I like to crack these before the draw. I am 1 card less likely to draw a land that way, thereby increasing my chances of drawing a nonland, which in most cases would be better than drawning another land. Not saying you are wrong, and I'm sure there are times where that play is 100% correct, but generally I like to thin my deck prior to drawing.

4/5 for me

EDIT: spelling

243454: Selesnya Sanctuary.author: Gear61
243454: Selesnya Sanctuary.text_parsed:
@BastianQoU

The card needs both of these drawbacks in order to make it fair. If it didn't bounce a land, it would be a free rampant growth. If it didn't come into play tapped, it's a free mana because you can tap the land you're going to bounce before you bounce it. (Imagine T2: Tap land from T1, bounce it with this, add 2 more mana, play your 3 drop on T2 with minimal effort).

Like ClockwordSwordfish said, the tempo loss is minimal, and the card is well worth the card advantage and fixing it provides. If you have this in your 2-lander hand, you're pretty safe, because you essentially have 3 lands in hands, while a normal 2-land is usually somewhat risky.

243464: Bogardan Hellkite.author: Larvald
243464: Bogardan Hellkite.text_parsed: Might not look spectacular at first glance, from a mathematical standpoint, but this is a beautiful and destructive late game bomb in casual play, particularly in red mana ramp decks.  It isn't its raw power, but rather its usability and versatility that make it good - it can be flashed in to wipe out attackers, or throw its 5 damage at an opponent and attack on the next turn for a finisher in a burn deck.  It's carried me to many victories.

243466: Cinder Wall.author: Mode
243466: Cinder Wall.text_parsed:
"@ Brocolli: your point about it's toughness helping it survive is moot if you ... read the text."
@lorendorky: Your point about it's toughness helping it survive being moot is moot if you ... read the text.

In other words, you didn't quite get alucard311's point.
This is a print from Duel Decks: Knights vs. Dragons; he refered to this card's use in the dragon deck against the knight deck. And in the knight deck are many 2/2 first strikers.

He is well aware that the wall won't survive combat due to its ability, but that doesn't mean toughness doesn't matter. if it was just a 3/2 for example, it wouldn't be able to deal any damage because it wouldn't survive the first strike from the knight.
And dealing damage to kill the attacking knight doesn't sound irrelevant at all.

Also, please learn your hómophones. The wall is not toughness, it has toughness: its toughness.
(Although in this case i have to admit - since the main point of this comment is about the wall being good against knights because of its ability to survive first strike - you could call the wall quite 'a toughness' :P)

243467: Bloodmark Mentor.author: Salient
243467: Bloodmark Mentor.text_parsed: I love this guy--a first-striking Ball Lightning is hilarious!--but his lack of use just indicates the problem with first strike. Whenever players have a choice between granting first strike and something like granting +1/+1, or haste, or flying, or nearly anything else, the latter sees play. It might just be that decks haven't figured out how to optimize the advantage first strike offers.

243471: Dragonspeaker Shaman.author: Madrai
243471: Dragonspeaker Shaman.text_parsed:
I was using this card for the longest time in my dragon deck, I'm glad the little guy made his way into the Duel Deck. -Tear of a proud parent.- Anyways, I understand Dragon's claw, it fits the flavor of the deck, and armillary sphere works because... dragons like collecting shiny things? It looks like something you'd see in a rave.

But the reasons they only put in one dragonspeaker shaman are simple.
1) They didn't want dragons coming out for 2-3 mana. Dragons are large, majestic creatures, and their mana costs reflect that.
2) They wanted it to be a card you wanted to draw, making it rare to get inside the deck. A casual new player who draws that card will love it all the more when it's one of a kind.
3) If a casual player wanted more, then they'll have to go out and buy another duel deck package. Excellent scheme on the part of Wizards. Well played.

I already plan to buy at least five Knights versus Dragons, four for myself to Build powerful casual theme decks around, and one for my kids. I'm sure my daughter will want the dragons. She makes me so proud. :D

243480: Armillary Sphere.author: humor_love
243480: Armillary Sphere.text_parsed:
This seems pretty powerful - probably competes with Darksteel Ingot (and even Gilded Lotus) among artifacts that support multi-colored efforts - which can be more helpful or simply better in many decks than Green's abilities to provide similar assistance (because, for one thing, not all multi-colored decks are able or wanting to include Green).

However, in decks that do contain Green - and even in mono-Green decks - the Sphere has great synergy with the solid and playable Explore.

243480: Armillary Sphere.author: blurrymadness

Something very nice about this is that it prevents you from missing your third turn land drop if you were going to. (Drop this t2. crack it t3 if you didn't draw a land.) meaning it helps not only with color screw and things, but it helps with mulligans and such.

Colorless, card advantage, deck thinning. I'm thinking of possibly replacing some lands in a deck with this. Need a powerful 1-drop to do that though; maybe Steppe Lynx :D

243482: Breath of Darigaaz.author: SparkleTiger
243482: Breath of Darigaaz.text_parsed:
This card is brutal! Unless they have a Knight Exemplar, this pretty much wipes the board of any knights. And even outside of the Knights v. Dragons set, this card is awesome. If you need to wipe pesky Eldrazi Spawns, Saprolings, or tiny, unpumped Elves, the unkicked option works well too. Solid card.

If playing a big multiplayer game and I'm looking for a full board wipe, I prefer Chain Reaction for obvious reasons. But this card doesn't hit your fliers if your running a Dragon deck.
4/5

243484: Spitting Earth.author: Mode
243484: Spitting Earth.text_parsed:
"By build a deck around it you mean use snow mountains, or just snow lands and splash red. Skred is better" --nope.avi

Well, there aren't any snow dual/shock lands, so it won't be as efficient if you splash any other colors.
Sacred Foundry for example will work with Spitting Earth, but not with Skred.
So you might end up dealing more damage with this sorcery.
But yeah, even then you might prefer paying one less for slightly less damage if it's still sufficient to kill the creature.
And in simply structured, monored decks, Skred and Snow-Covered Mountains is always what you'd want to play instead.

Also, Skred is an Instant, which in comparison to Seismic Strike makes it even cheaper.

@Escef actually, it's a reprint of a functional reprint of Ghitu War Cry! :D

Since it uses the original art, you can tell it's from Kamigawa block.
Maybe you forgot about it since this block wasn't overall that well received, but each of its expansions had one influential artifact in it: Sensei's Divining Top (Champions of Kamigawa), Umezawa's Jitte (Betrayers of Kamigawa) and Pithing Needle (Saviors of Kamigawa, the expansion where this card was originally from).

243486: Ghostfire.author: Salient
243486: Ghostfire.text_parsed:
One of the most flavorful cards from the intense potpourri of Future Sight, finally given proper form. This is gorgeous. Cyril Van Der Haegen's spectacular art, nearly impossible to appreciate through the original Future Sight frame, gets its day in the colorless sun! :)

Failing to find room for this in Rise of the Eldrazi (and failing to follow up on colorless spells costing less than ) was a huge disappointment from the Creative team, and this reprint is as close to an apology as we're likely to receive. So hey, thanks. It's something.

243486: Ghostfire.author: DarthParallax
243486: Ghostfire.text_parsed:
Hmm....I don't think we've seen the last of the Eldrazi. Granted, Wizards' current modus operandi for story writing seems to be just slightly more organized and restrained than DC Comics, but after the first 'MTG Crisis on Infinite Earths' in Future Sight, we might be able to expect some sort of Blackest Night, or New 52-esque 'push this giant red button and see what happens' block....a block that would unite the current arch-stories of The Eldrazi, Nicol Bolas, and a few key Planeswalkers. Don't ever expect a card with the name 'Jace' ever again, but I think we are not done with him in the webcomics just yet....oh, and there's the whole 'both New Phyrexia and Karn are back now.'

None of our previous Planeswalkers spoiled so far has come across as being able to fill the post of 'Red Ranger' against Nicol Bolas' 'Lord Zedd'. That is to say, each might have personal potential, but nobody looks like much of a team player so far. In fact, last I checked everyone from the Lorwyn 5 and the Alara 5 kind of all hated each other. Karn, however, totally fits the 'Leader of the Good Guys' bill, against similar foes in the past. Karn can even sub in for Ugin (who I suspect is dead at the hands of Bolas) as a source of colorless Magic to counteract the Eldrazi with, and he's one of the few 'good guys' I could see working alongside Sorin out of practicality and necessity. Expect a New Coalition sometime very very soon. Like, maybe even This Fall-type soon.

243486: Ghostfire.author: DoragonShinzui
243486: Ghostfire.text_parsed:
It used to be that I thought this was overcosted because Incinerate cost less and could deal with regeneration, which is the bane of burn spells, rather than this being overcosted because of Lightning Bolt. Lightning Bolt is just too powerful guys, we all know this.

And now Wizards have printed Searing Spear, which is not only strictly worse than Incinerate AND Lightning Bolt, but is just a boring pile of underwhelming blandness. And now I KNOW that this card is overcosted as all hell. Protection from Red isn't that big of a deal. Red has ways around it, namely, nuking the player instead. There was no conceivable reason to price this at . None. I mean, had it been priced at , that would have been an entirely different story. That's colorless burn, I'm all for that. This is just burn that can get through an uncommon problem at an insane cost. It's just stupid.

For that reason, I can only give this card a 2/5, and that's even being generous with the flavor points. This card is just too expensive to justify throwing into a deck, and as sideboard tech, there are better options around. Again, just burn your opponent.

Want to make people hate you in EDH?

All right, here goes.

You're playing Scion of the Ur-Dragon. Lucky you, you have the to play your Scion. By some small act of god, your general survives his first turn out and it's now your turn, he's ready to swing, and that one pesky opponent doesn't have a flier out.

According to the explanation given with the banning, this was the card in storm decks that was the easiest to ban which allowed "frequent" 3rd turn wins, which is a no-no in modern. They didn't want to completely invalidate storm decks, so they gave it a limp instead.

243490: Temporary Insanity.author: DarthParallax
243490: Temporary Insanity.text_parsed:
Im giving this card 3 and a half stars, and I understand that sounds outrageous to some, so let me explain:

Every so often, I like digging REALLY deep back into the past of DailyMTG to look up Mirrodin-period and pre-Mirrodin-period articles, especially in Making Magic and Latest Developments.

I found the article that mentions when this card was creadted, and why. It is the first Red 'Ray of Command'- (the first 'gain control of target creature until end of turn' effect in that color.)

The reason I rate this high is because it looks like such a great design to represent what is going on by moving that part of the color pie over to red. In blue, gaining control of target creature doesn't have much to do with the creature itself- pick a creature, and creature, the point is you want something and your going to take it. Putting the ability in Red immediately switches all the attention to the creature: its motives, its passions.

Ray of Command, Mind Control, and Control Magic all mostly emphasize the new controller gaining a minion. Temporary Insanity, Mark of Mutiny, and Act of Treason all emphasize the creature switching allegiances. In particular, they open the possibility that the creature is doing so of their own free will, albeit not thinking clearly at the time (hence the temporariness). It makes sense therefore that in addition to 'just' Ray of Commanding, a red card should have some extra line of text relevant to the creature, like adding +1/+1 or defining what kind of creature you can take.

My favorite mental image for a Red steal card is when Anakin Skywalker falls to the Dark Side and becomes Darth Vader in Episode III Revenge of the Sith- that was an Act of Treason Marking his Mutiny resulting from Temporary Insanity.

The card has the exact same cost as Ray of Command, except its red. This helps it to be recognized by players familiar with the Blue card, and connecting it to that card by mirroring the mana cost helps to communicate the whole concept better. If, for example, there were ever going to be a card like '1W: Destroy target black attacking creature' or something like that, then costing 1W, the same as Doom Blade except in color, is important so that you can quickly make the jump to 'this is White Doom Blade'.

Those kinds of 'tells' may not be as important for experienced players as new ones, but since the game needs new players, it needs to invest some thought and attention to the new players as well as the old hats.

All I'm saying is, from a design standpoint, this card seems to be a perfect execution, even if the modern Act of Treason is 'strictly better'.

My favorite mental image for a Red steal card is when Anakin Skywalker falls to the Dark Side and becomes Darth Vader in Episode III Revenge of the Sith- that was an Act of Treason Marking his Mutiny resulting from Temporary Insanity.

The card has the exact same cost as Ray of Command, except its red. This helps it to be recognized by players familiar with the Blue card, and connecting it to that card by mirroring the mana cost helps to communicate the whole concept better. If, for example, there were ever going to be a card like '1W: Destroy target black attacking creature' or something like that, then costing 1W, the same as Doom Blade except in color, is important so that you can quickly make the jump to 'this is White Doom Blade'.

Those kinds of 'tells' may not be as important for experienced players as new ones, but since the game needs new players, it needs to invest some thought and attention to the new players as well as the old hats.

All I'm saying is, from a design standpoint, this card seems to be a perfect execution, even if the modern Act of Treason is 'strictly better'.

@igniteice: Grab the Reins doesnt untap the creature. With this you can wait for him to commit to an attck, untap his creature and block with it, and maybe get a 2-for-1 while you're at it. Grab the Reins doesnt untap the creature, so when using it as an instant you would have to use it before attackers are declared, at which point he may just not attack and you payed 4 CMC for a red fog.

Sure, GTR is better over-all, but not in EVERY way.

243490: Temporary Insanity.author: Mode
243490: Temporary Insanity.text_parsed:
I think the main thought behind this card was that besides having an Act of Treason on your turn, you could also do use this card in an opponent's turn to grab and untap one of his attackers and use it to block another one from them to kill them each other.
The power restriction just makes it a bit tricky to use.

Regarding the use in this duel deck, i think it's pretty decent: You have various sorceries and instants, and small creatures like Skirk Prospector and Cinder Wall lying in your graveyard.
If there's a Knight Exemplar or Kinsbaile Cavalier, you can either choose one of them or another knight from their side, either way some knights will get weaker and make it easer for you to kill at least one. Knight of Meadowgrain for example nets you some life and can be used to kill it and either of them (if just one of them is on the field)
Grab their Knight of the Reliquary, and it becomes a 2/2 on your side that will get easily killed.
And you also have 2 Mudbutton Torchrunners in the deck that can help with these combat tricks.

So i think this was an interesting choice to put in the dragon deck.

243490: Temporary Insanity.author: igniteice
243490: Temporary Insanity.text_parsed:
@Elleran
The instant doesn't make this card better than Act of Treason. Act of Treason is a sorcery and costs 1 less, hardly comparable as they are used in different contexts. If you want to compare this card to something, compare it to Grab the Reins. Same rarity, instant, same cost, but with no restrictions. And icing on the cake: an entwine option to sac the creature you gained control of and have it deal direct damage to target player. Grab the Reins is better in every way.

@BuffJittePLZ
Point taken, but I still wouldn't run with this. It requires you to have cards in your graveyard, something that can't be gauranteed. May be slightly easier with a burn deck, but still. It's far too situational though to rely on. I'd much rather sacrafice speed for usability. Furthermore, now with Traitorous Blood out, there are even better options. Less mana and trample at sorcery? Sure.
